This report was prepared by Shunso Tsukada, Senior Transport Specialist, Transport and 
Communications Division, South Asia Department.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During  the  2003  Country  Programming  Mission,  the  Government  of  India  (the 
Government) requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to extend technical assistance 
(TA) for preparing the National Highways Sector II Project (the 2004 Project).1 The ADB TA 
Fact-Finding  Mission2 visited India from 10 to 13 March 2003. The paper for the TA was 
prepared based on the findings and understandings reached with the Government during the 
mission. The findings of the initial poverty and social assessment are summarized in Appendix 
1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  India’s economy has long suffered from a chronic shortage of its highway system 
capacity. Of the national highway systems, 38% comprised single lanes, 58% is two-lane, while 
only 2% is four-lane or more. Due to the inadequate capacity, the Government has decided to 
launch a radical program of upgrading key national highway corridors in 10 years. The highways 
to be improved include the (i) Golden Quadrilateral—6,000 kilometers (km); (ii) North-South 
Corridor—4,000 km; and (iii) East-West Corridor—3,300 km. The program, called the National 
Highway Development Program was announced in 1998 and is to be completed by the end of 
2007. The total cost of the program is estimated at $13 billion. 
 
3.  Effective  implementation  of  a  program  of  this  magnitude  requires  establishing  an 
appropriate policy and institutional environment. The Government had taken a series of actions 
to create such an environment. The main actions taken include (i) simplifying century-old land 
acquisition procedures by amending the National Highway Act; (ii) issuing and implementing a 
new policy guideline3 for private sector participation in highway development; (iii) adopting a 
policy that, once a national highway is upgraded to a four-lane standard, it is to be converted 
into a toll roads; (iv) revamping the central road fund by introducing additional excise duties 
levied on petrol and diesel; and (v) delegating broader decision-making authority to the National 
Highway Authority of India (NHAI) so that it can make decisions on individual investments and 
procurement without being subjected to lengthy administrative approval processes.  
 
4.  While the policy actions have brought about significant changes in the ways managing 
national highways, a number of issues remain. To address the remaining issues in an effective 
and systematic manner, ADB has adopted a programmatic approach since 2001. An essential 
element of the programmatic approach is to set out the medium-to-long-term goals for ADB’s 
interventions for the national highway subsector and pursue the realization of these goals in a 
progressive and evolutionary manner through its multiyear lending program rather than on a 
project-by-project  basis.  These  medium-to-long-term  goals  include  (i)  strengthening  the 
institutional capacity for project implementation and contract management; (ii) strengthening 
financing and financial management capability so as to effectively mobilize necessary funds 
from  capital  markets;  (iii)  instituting  effective  highway  operations  and  maintenance  (O&M) 
systems; (iv) advancing the public-private partnership (PPP) approach; and (v) through these 
actions, transforming NHAI into a financially and managerially autonomous body. 
 
5.  In support of the National Highway Development Program, ADB provided three loans to 
NHAI during 2000–2002 and is processing another loan. The first project was Surat-Manor

Project (approved in 2000), which provided NHAI with a $180 million loan for upgrading the 180 
km  stretch  of  Golden  Quadrilateral  in  Maharashtra.4  The  project  was  a  straightforward 
investment project that introduced outsourcing of O&M to the private sector. The second project, 
the Western Transport Corridor Project (approved in 2001), provided a loan of $240 million for 
upgrading anther 259 km stretch of Golden Quadrilateral in Karnataka State.5 The Western 
Transport Corridor Project initiated the programmatic approach by setting out the medium-term 
objectives of ADB’s lending operations to NHAI. The third project was the East-West Corridor 
Project, a $320 million loan (approved in 2002).6 The project financed the 504 km stretch of the 
East-West Corridor in Gujarat, and was designed to implement the programmatic approach by 
requiring (i) specific actions as the project proceeds, and (ii) that part of the project roads be 
developed under the PPP scheme. The fourth loan is the National Highway Corridor (Sector) I 
Project (the 2003 Project), which is to finance 640 km of the East-West Corridor, with an 
estimated loan of $400 million. As a part of the programmatic approach, the 2003 Project will 
also address key policy and institutional issues with particular emphasis on O&M. The Project is 
a sector loan, is aimed at instituting standardized project preparation and processing processes, 
and at strengthening NHAI’s quality control capability for highway design and construction by  
establishing a technical team in NHAI’s project team.   
 
6.  The proposed 2004 Project is the second sector loan. The 2004 Project will finance 
approximately 600–700 km of highways in the North-South  Corridor,  in  Utter  Pradesh  and 
Madhya Pradesh states. Approximately 15% of the highways will be financed by the private 
sector. The Project build on ongoing efforts to standardize project development and approval 
processes  and  strengthen  NHAI’s  institutional  capability  for  the  project  development  and 
processing. The Project will aim at expanding the use of technical teams throughout NHAI. The 
2004 Project will also address key policy and institutional issues as a part of the programmatic 
approach. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
7.  The TA is designed to facilitate the preparation and processing of the 2004 Project for 
upgrading selected parts of the North-South Corridor with particular focus on environmental 
protection and social development aspects. The primary function of the TA consultants is, thus, 
to ensure that ADB’s safeguard policies are adequately incorporated and implemented in the 
Project. The TA consultants will also assist NHAI to develop parts of the project roads under 
PPP schemes.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  NHAI will carry out feasibility studies, the preliminary design, the resettlement plan, the 
environmental impact assessment (EIA) or initial environmental examination (IEE), the detailed 
design, and development of bidding documents, through its own consulting firms. The primary 
role of the TA consultants is to supplement NHAI efforts for project preparation and processing, 
and make sure that analyses and plans are consistent with ADB’s requirements.

 9.  The 2004 Project will consist of core subprojects, which will be appraised by ADB; and 
noncore subprojects, which will be appraised by NHAI in accordance with agreed guidelines. 
For core subprojects, the TA consultants will assist NHAI by focusing specific assistance such 
as  summary  environment  assessments  and  summary  resettlement  plans.  For  noncore 
subprojects,  the  consultants  will  provide  sector-oriented  assistance,  such  as  environment 
assessments, resettlement frameworks, or indigenous people frameworks. The main tasks of 
the TA consultants are described on the following paragraphs. 
 
1.  Environmental Impact Assessment 
 
10.  The TA consultant, an environmental specialist, will review, verify, and (if necessary) 
revise the environmental assessments by NHAI consultants for core subprojects, to ensure that 
all ADB’s requirements are adequately incorporated in accordance with ADB’s  Environment 
Policy and Environmental Assessment Guidelines. The specialist will prepare summary EIAs or 
IEEs for core subprojects, and will undertake strategic environmental assessment for the North-
South Corridor. 
 
2.  Resettlement  
 
11.  The TA consultant, a resettlement specialist, will review, verify, and (if necessary) revise 
the resettlement plans to be prepared by NHAI consultants to ensure that all requirements are 
adequately incorporated in accordance with ADB’s Policy on Involuntary Resettlement and its 
Handbook on Resettlement. The specialist will prepare summary resettlement plans for core 
subprojects. The specialist will provide necessary guidance for NHAI consultants in developing 
resettlement plans for noncore subprojects. The specialist will prepare a resettlement framework 
for the entire Project.  
 
3.  Emerging Social Issues 
 
12.  The TA consultant, a social development specialist, will undertake social assessment in 
accordance with ADB’s Handbook for Poverty Reduction and Social Assessment, addressing 
key  social  issues  such  as  land  acquisition,  resettlement,  poverty,  indigenous  people, 
communicable  disease,  gender  issues,  labor  (including  child  labor),  and  stakeholder 
participation. The specialist will carry out necessary surveys on indigenous peoples along 
project influence areas, and, if necessary, develop indigenous people development plans for 
core subprojects. In addition, the specialist will develop an indigenous people development 
framework. The specialist should also determine the possible impact of the Project on trafficking 
of women and children.  
 
4.  Poverty Impact Assessment 
 
13.  The TA consultant, a transport economist, will conduct a poverty impact assessment in 
accordance with ADB’s Handbook for Integrating Poverty Impact Assessment in the Economic 
Analysis of Projects. The assessment will cover (i) a poverty profile of the project influence 
areas, including the definition of people below the poverty line and income disparities between 
groups of society, districts, and states; (ii) the relationship between transport and poverty, 
including an analysis of usage patterns of transport services by the poor; (iii) a description of 
social programs that are undertaken by central or state governments and by external aid 
agencies, and that are likely to contribute to the poverty reduction in the project areas; (iv) a 
community-based  assessment  of  the  impact  of  the  Project  on  poverty  reduction;  and  (v) 
quantitative analyses on the impact of the Project for poverty reduction including the calculation 
of poverty impact ratio. The TA economist will prepare a five-page note covering the above

4 
issues for the core subprojects. The economist will refine, if necessary, the poverty impact 
assessment guideline previously developed for noncore subprojects during processing of the 
2003 Project. 
 
5.  Development of the PPP Scheme 
 
14.  The TA consultant, a project finance specialist, will identify the highway section(s) to be 
developed under the PPP scheme. For sections suitable for the PPP scheme, the specialist will 
conduct surveys necessary for traffic projection, assess possible deviation or generation of the 
traffic,  develop  tolling  strategies,  and  assess  the  financial  viability  of  the  proposed  PPP 
component(s) including the grant amount to be paid by NHAI to make the PPP component(s) 
financially viable. The specialist will also design the structure of PPP concession, and, based on 
that, make necessary modifications to the model concession agreements developed by the 
Government  for  highway  development.  The  specialist  will  also  structure  main  elements  of 
bidding including prequalification criteria and selection criteria of bidders.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $380,000 equivalent, consisting of $243,900 in 
foreign exchange and $136,100 equivalent in local currency costs. ADB will finance $300,000 
equivalent on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The remaining $80,000 equivalent 
will be contributed by the Government, and will include office accommodation, counterpart staff 
remuneration, transportation, and surveys. The cost estimates and financing plan are detailed in 
Appendix 2. The Government has been informed that ADB’s financing of the TA does not 
commit ADB to finance a subsequent loan project.   
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  NHAI will be the Executing Agency. NHAI will form a project team headed by the chief 
general manager. A technical team will be established under the project team. The primary 
functions of the technical team will be to (i) review and examine all technical reports, including 
the feasibility studies, preliminary design, resettlement plans, EIAs/IEEs, and detailed design 
reports, to ensure the requirements of ADB and NHAI are fully met; and (ii) evaluate the overall 
viability of noncore subprojects and prepare a summary appraisal report to be submitted to ADB 
for its approval.  
 
17.  The consultants will be engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB on the selection and engagement of 
domestic consultants. The task requires 8.5 person-months input of four international individual 
consultants and 4 person-months input of a domestic consultant. 
 
18.  The TA will commence in October 2003 and be finished in August 2004. Terms of 
reference for the consulting services are outlined in Appendix 3. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of India for preparing the National Highways Sector II Project, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

SUMMARY INITIAL POVERTY AND SOCIAL ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis 
Sector identified as a national priority in country  Sector identified as a national priority in country 
poverty analysis?  No  poverty partnership agreement?  No 
 
Contribution of the Road Sector to Reduce Poverty in India: 
 
While the sector is not a core sector for poverty alleviation in India, road infrastructure is a key instrument 
for alleviating the poverty. This is one reason for the substantial allocation of money for the road sector in 
the 10th Five-Year Plan of the Government of India. The Government’s road development policy is to 
establish well-connected and well-managed national highway, state road, and rural road systems. The 
Asian Development Bank intends to assist the Government through lending to all three levels of road 
systems, i.e. national highway, state road, and rural road systems.   
 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Proposed Classification 
 
Proposed Classification:  Others. Thematic  (Economic growth and private sector development). 
 
Poverty Analysis:  The proposed Project will broadly cover parts of the North-South Corridor in the 
states of Uttar Pradesh and Madhya Pradesh. 
 
 
Uttar Pradesh and Madhya Pradesh rank among the lowest of India’s states in terms of the Human 
Development Index. Many districts along the project roads are far below than the national averages. Even 
with the many rivers and seasonal streams, the agricultural productivity is low as the black soil is not very 
fertile and few irrigation facilities are available. The undulating terrain restricts the development of irrigation 
systems. Deforestation has eroded the forest-based livelihood of many communities.   
 
The project roads pass through five districts (Jhansi, Lalitpur, Narsimhpur, Sagar, and Seoni), which are 
among the country’s most underdeveloped areas. These districts are characterized by some of the lowest 
levels of per capita income and human development in the country. Literacy levels are poor, especially 
among women, and infant mortality is relatively high. Local inhabitants primarily rely on subsistence 
rainfed single crop agriculture and small-scale livestock production for their livelihood, with wheat, grams, 
and oil seeds being the predominant crops. Population density in the region largely correlates to such 
factors as soil types, natural vegetation, industrialization, and urbanization. In rural areas, rising population 
has led to fragmented family land holdings. These factors, combined with limited rainfall and scarce fresh 
water resources, have resulted in low agricultural productivity. Many families are no longer able to meet 
their subsistence needs. Temporary and long-term migration of male workers from rural communities to 
urban areas in search of alternative sources of livelihood has become increasingly a problem.  
 
These states believe that an improved transport system is a key for the economic growth of these regions, 
and have given their highest priority to the development of highway system.  It is their view that, without 
economic growth, their efforts for poverty reduction are not sustainable.  Rural communities have indicated 
rural roads to be the area of highest priority for the improvement of their livelihood.

10  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will be carried out by a team of individual consultants 
consisting  of  (i)  an  international  environmental  specialist,  (ii)  an  international  resettlement 
specialist; (iii) a domestic social development specialist; (iv) an international transport economist 
with extensive experience in poverty analysis; and (v) an international project finance specialist. 
The total input of the services by these international consultants will be 8.5 person-months, 
while that of the domestic consultant will be 4 person-months. 
 
2.  The main tasks of the TA consultants are as follows:  
 
1.  Environmental Specialist (1 person-month) 
 
3.  An  international  environmental  specialist  will  be  engaged  to  review,  verify,  and  if 
necessary  revise  the  environmental  assessment  to  be  carried  out  by  National  Highways 
Authority of India (NHAI) consultants for core subprojects, to ensure that all Asian Development 
Bank  (ADB)  requirements  are  adequately  covered  in  accordance  with  ADB’s Environment 
Policy  and  Environmental  Assessment  Guidelines.  The  specialist  will  prepare  summary 
environmental impact assessments or summary initial environmental examinations for core 
subprojects, and will undertake a strategic environmental assessment for the North-South 
Corridor.1  
 
2.  Resettlement Specialist (3 person-months) 
 
4.  An international resettlement specialist will be engaged to review, verify, and edit the 
resettlement plans to be prepared by NHAI consultants, to ensure that all requirements are 
adequately covered in accordance with ADB’s  Policy on Involuntary Resettlement  and its 
Handbook on Resettlement. The specialist will (i) prepare summary resettlement plans for core 
subprojects; provide necessary guidance for NHAI consultants who develop resettlement plans 
for subprojects, both core and noncore subprojects; (iii) provide necessary guidance for NHAI 
consultants who develop resettlement plans for noncore subprojects; (iv) prepare a resettlement 
framework for the entire Project; and (v) engage local experts for conducting necessary surveys.  
 
3.  Social Development Specialist (4 person-months) 
 
5.  A  domestic  social  development  specialist  will  be  engaged  to  undertake  social 
assessment  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Handbook  for  Poverty  Reduction  and  Social 
Assessment, addressing key social issues such as land acquisition, resettlement, poverty, 
indigenous peoples, communicable diseases, gender issues, labor issues including child labor, 
and stakeholders’ participation. The specialist will also (i) carry out necessary surveys on 
indigenous peoples living in the project influence areas, and, if necessary, develop indigenous 
peoples development plans; (ii) develop an indigenous peoples development framework; (iii) 
determine the possible impact of the Project on trafficking of women and children; and (iv) 
engage local experts for conducting the surveys.

4.  Transport  Economist  for  the  Poverty  Impact  Assessment  (1.5  person-
months) 
 
6.  An international transport economist will be engaged to analyze the poverty reduction 
impact of the core subprojects. The analysis will cover (i) a poverty profile of the project 
influence areas, including the definition of people below the poverty line and income disparities 
between groups of society, districts, and states; (ii) the relationship between transport and 
poverty, including an analysis of use pattern of transport systems by the poor; (iii) a description 
of social programs by central or state governments and by external aid agencies that are likely 
to contribute to poverty reduction in the project areas; (iv) a community-based assessment of 
the impact of the Project on poverty reduction; and (v) quantitative analyses of the impact of the 
Project on poverty reduction, including the calculation of poverty impact ratio. The poverty 
analysis is to be carried out in accordance with ADB’s Handbook for Integrating Poverty Impact 
Assessment in the Economic Analysis of Projects. If necessary, the economist will refine the 
poverty impact assessment guidelines developed for noncore subprojects during the processing 
stage of the 2003 Project.  
5.  Project Finance Specialist (3 person-months) 
 
7.  An international project finance specialist will be engaged to identify highway sections to 
be developed under a public private partnership (PPP) scheme and design an investment 
package for the PPP components. The specialist’s first task will be to screen the project roads 
and identify the sections to be developed under the PPP scheme. For sections suitable for the 
PPP scheme, the specialist will conduct surveys necessary for traffic projection, assess possible 
deviation or generation of the traffic, develop tolling strategies, and assess the financial viability 
of the proposed PPP components, including the grant amount to be paid by NHAI to make the 
PPP component financially viable. The consultant will also design the structure of the PPP 
concession, and, based on that, modify the model concession agreements developed by the 
Government  for  highway  development.  The  specialist  will  also  structure  main  elements  of 
bidding, including prequalification criteria and criteria for selection of bidders.
